body:
Outdated license date. (2015 => 2016)

Simple as this. :)

title: Redcarped incorrectly handles emails with underscore char
body:
I.e. redcarpet hides `` (`

`) but shows `` (`

abc@def.com

`)

title: Give access to Markdown and rendering options
body:
Hi !

This is just a pull request that exposes the Markdown and rendering options through the `@options` instance variable which is just a Hash which mixes both options. Thus, custom callbacks can return an output based upon these settings.

Closes #205.

title: Support for latex equations
body:
Many wikis support rendering of Latex equations by just including a MathJax or KaTeX JavaScript file in the header. Then equations embedded between "$" (inline) or "$$" (block) are processed when the page is loaded.

Unfortunately this works poorly in Markdown, since Latex uses heavily "_", which is interpreted as emphasis.

It would be great if there was an option in redcarpet to treat all content between one or two dollar signs verbatim (similar to "`").

title: underscores in email addresses are not rendered correctly
body: With these settings: ```ruby opts = { filter_html: true, safe_links_only: false } renderer = Redcarpet::Render::HTML.new(opts) extensions = { autolink: true } @markdown_renderer = Redcarpet::Markdown.new(renderer, extensions) ``` I'm trying to render this: ```md x_b_and_c@bar.com ``` But it gets rendered as: ```html xband_c@bar.com ``` I've also tried these in markdown: ``` [x_b_and_c@bar.com](mailto:x_b_and_c@bar.com) x\_b\_and\_c@bar.com ``` None of them seem to produce the right output, which should be this: ```html x_b_and_c@bar.com ```

title: Use :safe_links_only only for automatic links
body:
I think the `:safe_links_only` should be used only for automatic linking. So when there is text like:

> Chat with us on irc://example.com/room

It must not be rendered as link, because `irc://` schema is not in the safe links.

However when rendering an actual Markdown link like:

> Chat with us on [#room](irc://example.com)

The link should be rendered. All links with the `[anchor text](URI)` should be rendered. Otherwise this is quite limiting.

Of course all attributes should be escaped even the `href` attributes in the `[]()` links.

So I think this should stay: https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/blob/df1b85d77fc9c962237ca48b498395c40d012a52/ext/redcarpet/html.c#L89-L92

But this should not check for safe URI schemas: https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/blob/df1b85d77fc9c962237ca48b498395c40d012a52/ext/redcarpet/html.c#L329-L330

A real world example from GitHub:
- [Raw Markdown (see Community)](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/composer/composer/40c14709f79f9d7ea35ac969cfbd7f41beb525bb/README.md)
- [Rendered Markdown with missing irc:// links](https://github.com/composer/composer/blob/40c14709f79f9d7ea35ac969cfbd7f41beb525bb/README.md#community)

title: tables: all rows that are longer than the thead row are truncated
body:
Given this markdown (as `test.md`): ```markdown 0,0 | 0,1 | 0,2 | --- | --- | --- | --- 1,0 | 1,1 | 1,2 | 1,3 2,0 | 2,1 | 2,2 | 2,3 ``` Running `redcarpet --parse-tables < test.md` results in the following output: ```html
0,0 0,1 0,2
1,0 1,1 1,2
2,0 2,1 2,2
``` As you can see above, cells `1,3` and `2,3` are missing from the output, and I think that's a bug. This behavior hides content that could be important to readers, without so much as a parser error. And that can be a pain when you're not carefully checking what your markdown looks like after compilation. For example, an extra cell jutting out of an otherwise rectangular table, or a missing header is an easy error to spot, while a column missing still leaves the table looking correct and orderly. Even if you are looking at the output in a graphical/rendered form while you're editing, it's annoying to start a table cell in a new column and not be able to see what you are typing until you add a header for that column.

Hi,

Is there a way to override the CSS styling to introduce custom color schemes or create new styling to make the the CSS code generated responsive for mobile layouts?

Right now, it's not responsive on mobile layouts and breaks my current materialize layout on mobile devises.

title: List doesn't render unless blank line comes before the first list item
body:
It seems like lists are only render when theres a newline that interrupts a paragraph. Currently the way to render a list is: ``` test * test - test ``` But it should also include (http://spec.commonmark.org/0.24/#example-259): ``` test * test - test ``` Here's some irb showing this: ``` [17] pry(main)> markdown = Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::XHTML, options) => #> [18] pry(main)> content1 = "test\n\n* test" => "test\n\n* test" [19] pry(main)> content2 = "test\n* test" => "test\n* test" [20] pry(main)> markdown.render(content1) => "

test

\n\n
    \n
  • test
    • \n
\n" [21] pry(main)> markdown.render(content2) => "

test\n* test

\n" ``` I came up with a workaround in an app that uses redcarpet. Just uses a preprocess to add another newline before a list: ``` def preprocess(text_content) text_content.gsub(/^\w+\n(?=[*|-]\s\w+)/, "\\0\n") end ``` I'm wonder... is this is expected? Totally low priority and just a nitpick. Just curious. Thanks!

title: List not compiling
body: Silly question though... The following has been failed in compiling. Did I miss something? ```markdown --- # layout: post # ... --- ### The Next "Big Thing" Security & Trust #### Mobile Solutions – Mobile financial services - ... #### Embedded Solutions – M2M communications – ... ``` Compiled and rendered is Below is the `_config.yml` ```yml markdown: "redcarpet" redcarpet: extensions: - smart - fenced_code_blocks - autolink - tables - strikethrough - superscript - underline - highlight - quote - footnote_ref highlighter: pygments # ... ```

title: Code block with non-empty lines before them not being recognized
body:
Code blocks do not appear to be recognized if the line before them is not empty when using the `Redcarpet::Render::HTML` renderer and with `fenced_code_blocks: true`. For example a code block with an empty line before test ```ruby x = 1 ``` produces ```html

test

x = 1
``` but a code block with text before it test ```ruby x = 1 ``` produces ```html

test ruby x = 1

``` Is this expected behavior?

Brenton

title: Fix bufprintf for Windows MinGW-w64
body:
On MinGW-w64, `vsnprintf` returns `-1` when given buffer is small (it should return required length as defined in C99). Because of this, `bufprintf` sometime fails to write string to the given buffer, and header HTML tag (such as `

` and `

`) isn't outputed occasionally. Fix it by defining `__USE_MINGW_ANSI_STDIO`. (see https://github.com/oneclick/rubyinstaller/issues/186 for detail) Fixes #474

title: Ampersand (&) not rendered correctly in Table Of Contents
body:
Thank you for this excellent piece of open source software and all of the time you put into it. I think I might have found a small bug I just wanted to file. I looked at fixing it and submitting a PR, but the Markdown rendering is beyond me. **The problem:** When an ampersand character is present in a title, the `Redcarpet::Render::HTML_TOC` renderer converts the ampersand to "amp", but the `Redcarpet::Render::HTML` renderer removes the ampersand character. Because the 2 value don't match up, clicking the TOC link fails and doesn't direct you to the correct spot on the page. For now I am working around it by changing &'s in titles to "and". Another workaround I found was changing &'s to &'s, but I found that that was a less clear workaround. My Code ```ruby def get_document toc_renderer = Redcarpet::Render::HTML_TOC.new(nesting_level: 2) toc = Redcarpet::Markdown.new(toc_renderer) markdown_renderer = Redcarpet::Render::HTML.new(with_toc_data: true) markdown = Redcarpet::Markdown.new( markdown_renderer, no_intra_emphasis: true, tables: true, autolink: true, quote: true ) content = File.read(File.join(Rails.root, "library", "#{params[:document_path]}.md")) @frontmatter = yaml_frontmatter_metadata_from(content) content_without_frontmatter = remove_yaml_frontmatter_from(content) @toc_html = toc.render(content_without_frontmatter) @content_html = markdown.render(content_without_frontmatter) render layout: "columns_5_11_layout" end ``` The Markdown ```md # Section 1 ## Foo & Bar Blah blah blah ``` Rendered Table Of Contents ```html
  • Section 1
    • Foo & Bar
    • ``` Rendered H2 Output ```html

    Foo & Bar

    ``` Maybe this will help somebody else, or inform you on development. Thanks again for the time you put into redcarpet, I love it.

title: Fix header anchor normalization
body:
Do not call tolower on non-ASCII chars because it would otherwise
insert invalid UTF-8 bytes into the HTML output. (tolower is not
locale-aware)

Invalid UTF-8 bytes will cause various errors, e.g. "ArgumentError
(invalid byte sequence in UTF-8)", when rendering the generated HTML in
Rails.

This should fix #527.

Signed-off-by: Clemens Gruber <clemensgru@gmail.com>

title: Unicode headers produce invalid anchors
body:
When redcarpet processes Unicode headers to produce anchors (for use in TOC generation) it returns invalid anchors. The anchor claims to be in UTF-8, but it contains hexadecimal codes. Worse, the hexadecimal codes are not valid. For example, it returns `\xE3\xA9` instead of `\xC3\xA9` for an é. I suspect that what is happening is that the string has been incorrectly converted to lowercase, changing \xc3 to \xe3. The lowercase conversion has assumed latin1 encoding when it was actually utf-8. (HT : [Janne Karila](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14852224/unicode-latin1-string-encode-decode) Example : `irb(main):001:0> require 'redcarpet'` `=> true` `irb(main):002:0> markdown = Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::HTML_TOC)` `=> #>` `irb(main):003:0> test = "# Précis"` `=> "# Précis"` `irb(main):004:0> rc = markdown.render(test)` `=> "
    \n
  • \nPrécis\n
    • \n
\n"` `irb(main):005:0> test.encoding` `=> #` `irb(main):006:0> rc.encoding` `=> #` `irb(main):007:0> puts "pr\xC3\xA9cis"` `précis` `=> nil`

title: Definition lists
body:
Could you implement definition lists, please?

Here is some examples taken from other markdown dialects:
* [Markdown Extra](https://michelf.ca/projects/php-markdown/extra/#def-list)
* [Kramdown and Maruku](http://kramdown.gettalong.org/syntax.html#definition-lists)
* [MultiMarkdown](https://github.com/fletcher/MultiMarkdown/wiki/MultiMarkdown-Syntax-Guide#definition-lists)
* [Pandoc](http://pandoc.org/demo/example9/pandocs-markdown.html#definition-lists)
* [Python Markdown](http://pythonhosted.org/Markdown/extensions/definition_lists.html)
* [Lunamark](http://jgm.github.io/lunamark/lunamark.1.html)

Thank you!

title: Multiline tables
body:
Could you implement something similar to [Pandoc multiline tables](http://pandoc.org/README.html#tables), please?

Thank you!

title: Unable to compile native extensions in OS X "El Capitan"
body:
Hi! I got the following output when I tried to `gem install redcarpet -v '3.3.3'` on my macbook running OS X 10.11.

```
/usr/local/opt/rbenv/versions/2.1.5/bin/ruby extconf.rb
creating Makefile

make "DESTDIR=" clean

make "DESTDIR="
compiling autolink.c
compiling buffer.c
buffer.c:110:45: warning: passing 'const struct buf *' to parameter of type 'struct buf *' discards qualifiers [-Wincompatible-pointer-types-discards-qualifiers]
        if (buf->size + 1 <= buf->asize || bufgrow(buf, buf->size + 1) == BUF_OK) {
                                                   ^~~
buffer.c:59:21: note: passing argument to parameter 'buf' here
bufgrow(struct buf *buf, size_t neosz)
                    ^
1 warning generated.
compiling houdini_href_e.c
compiling houdini_html_e.c
compiling html.c
compiling html_smartypants.c
compiling markdown.c
markdown.c:2838:43: warning: passing 'const uint8_t *' (aka 'const unsigned char *') to parameter of type 'uint8_t *' (aka 'unsigned char *') discards qualifiers [-Wincompatible-pointer-types-discards-qualifiers]
                if (codefences_enabled && (is_codefence(document + beg, doc_size - beg, NULL) != 0))
                                                        ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~
markdown.c:1391:23: note: passing argument to parameter 'data' here
is_codefence(uint8_t *data, size_t size, struct buf *syntax)
                      ^
1 warning generated.
compiling rc_markdown.c
compiling rc_render.c
compiling stack.c
linking shared-object redcarpet.bundle
ld: library not found for -lgmp
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make: *** [redcarpet.bundle] Error 1

make failed, exit code 2
```

In particular, the line `ld: library not found for -lgmp` seemed odd to me. I didn't think that GMP was a dependency, so I poked around in the `ext/` directory and discovered that extconf added `-lgmp` to my cflags for some reason even though it's not mentioned in `extconf.rb` or anywhere.... Now that I've written this much, is this maybe an extconf bug? Not sure. I've already written this much already so....

title: Adding dependency badge to README
body: This project has no runtime dependencies. Keep up the good work.
